content.description: Figure 1. Four different bonds (<math alttext="W" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>W</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="Y" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Y</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="Z" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Z</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>) in a <math alttext="D N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> molecule
content.question: Figure 1 represents a segment of <math alttext="D N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Radiation can damage the nucleotides in a <math alttext="D N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> molecule. To repair some types of damage, a single nucleotide can be removed from a <math alttext="D N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> molecule and replaced with an undamaged nucleotide. Which of the four labeled bonds in Figure 1 could be broken to remove and replace the cytosine nucleotide without affecting the biological information coded in the <math alttext="D N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> molecule?

choices.label: Bonds <math alttext="Y" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Y</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="Z" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Z</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> at the same time

Bonds <math alttext="W" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>W</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="Z" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Z</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> at the same time

content.answer: Bonds <math alttext="Y" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Y</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="Z" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Z</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> at the same time

skill.text: 2.A: Describe characteristics of visual representations of biological concepts and processes.
